awd_titl_txt: Study of the Highest Energy Cosmic Rays with the Pierre Auger Observatory
awd_abstract_narration:
The discoveries made by the Pierre Auger Observatory (Auger) have transformed our understanding of ultra-high energy cosmic rays (UHECRs) and their sources.  This award supports the astro-particle groups at the Colorado School of Mines and Case Western Reserve University, who are major contributors in Auger with significant leadership roles.  They will carry out innovative studies of detector and energy systematics, atmospherics, and astrophysics.  Unraveling how UHECRs are accelerated has been the holy grail of multi-messenger astrophysics for a long time and requires the statistical power of Auger, augmented by an improved detector and by advanced data analysis methods.  Continued work to understand the relative and absolute energy scales of Auger will resolve existing discrepancies, both internal and with other experiments.  The research produces data that relate to climate change and convective storms: work is included to analyze those data, as well as data on aerosols, whose role in climate change is not well understood.  The groups will also continue their involvement with undergraduate design projects based around the research.

While energy spectrum measurements have firmly established the existence of flux suppression, composition studies suggest an evolution from light to heavier primaries above the ‘ankle’ that is seemingly incompatible with known effects.  The current measurements of energy spectra, anisotropy, particle composition, neutrino limits, photon limits, and p-air cross section demonstrate that Auger has an unprecedented view of the high-energy universe and access to particle physics at energies beyond the Large Hadron Collider.  Auger results will enable the groups to both use and understand the more subtle manifestations of UHECR sources in the sky.  In addition, this research investigates poorly understood initiation processes coming from heated electrons in the ionosphere, using the unique capabilities of the Auger Fluorescence Detector stations to study the Transient Luminescence Events known as elves.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Pierre Auger Observatory (Auger) is the world's largest cosmic ray observatory, spanning an area of 3000 square kilometers. It measures the highest energy subatomic particles known to exist. Their energies extend beyond 1020 electron volts, some 6 orders of magnitude above the reach of the most powerful man-made particle accelerator on Earth. While the sources of these "cosmic ray" particles remain unknown, they are expected to be produced in the most extreme environments in the universe. Analysis of data from Auger has shown that the sources lie beyond our Milky Way galaxy. From its vantage point near Malarague Argentina, Auger primarily views the southern sky, including the galactic center.  The world's second largest cosmic ray observatory, the  Telescope Array (TA) experiment, located in the Utah West Desert near the city of Delta, views the northern sky. There are puzzling differences in the sky maps of the cosmic ray arrival directions collected by the two experiments. TA has reported observations of a "hot" region with an excess of cosmic ray events at the 3 to 4 sigma level. While this falls below the 5-sigma standard for discovery, the observation is quite intriguing. In addition, the cosmic ray energy spectra as measured by the two experiments show energy slightly different energy scales and features, especially at the highest energies. This raises the question of how much of differences in the two data sets are due to instrumentational effects and much of these differences might be of astrophysical origin?

To address this question, this award funded the Colorado School of Mines Astroparticle Group together with the Astroparticle Group at CASE Western Reserve, to design, simulate, and install, at the TA site, a "cross-check" mini-array of ground-level detectors, dubbed Auger@TA, of the type used at the Auger Observatory.  A computer simulation was first performed to optimize a configuration for Auger@TA so that it could simultaneously measure, for direct comparison, a sub-set of cosmic ray events that were also measured by TA. Further simulation studies found that for cosmic ray events that landed inside the  Auger@TA mini array the energy resolution was 14% which is comparable to the energy resolutions of Auger and TA.

The Auger-style detectors are roto-molded 12 ft diameter plastic tanks, each filled with 12 tons of purified deionized water, and instrumented with sensitive light  photomultiplier sensors. Each tank includes a GPS clock for precise timing, a digitization system with a local buffer storage, a data WIFI microwave link and a solar power system to support remote autonomous operation. The photomultipliers detect the faint flashes of Cherenkov light inside the tank that are produced by charged particles created when the high energy cosmic ray interacts in the atmosphere and creates an extensive air-shower of secondary particles. The tanks sample the footprint of these particles, primarily electrons, and muons that reach the ground.

Although delayed by the Covid pandemic and by various procurement challenges, this logistically-intense objective was accomplished. The first phase of Auger@TA was the installation of two co-located stations, one TA detector station and one Auger water tank station, followed by the collection of simultaneous data from the two stations. The second phase was the deployment of an independently operated Auger@TA mini-array hexagon with eight Auger water tank within the Telescope Array (TA) experiment, The turn-on of this Auger@TA mini-array is in progress with the start of science data taking expected to begin shortly.
